text: Content Standard A: Mathematical facts, concepts, principles, and theories

children.text: Numeration: Understand and use numeration
Understanding Numbers

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of whole numbers to one thousand by
reading, writing, ordering, or [counting L] (M1.1.1)
modeling (base ten blocks) or identifying place value positions to thousands (M1.1.2)
using appropriate representations of ordinal or cardinal numbers (M1.1.4)

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of simple fractions wiht denominators 2, 3, 4 or 10 by
identifying, describing with explanations, or illustrating equal parts of a whole, a region, or a set (using models) (M1.1.5)
identifying, describing with explanations, or illustrating equivalent representation of fractions (using models) (M1.1.5)

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of whole numbers to ten thousands by
reading, writing, ordering, or [counting L] (M1.2.1)
modeling (base ten blocks) or identifying place value positions to ten thousands (M1.2.2)
t converting between whole numbers expressed in expanded notation and standard form (M1.2.4)

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of fractions with denominators_2 through 12 by
identifying, describing with explanations, or illustrating equal parts of a whole, a region, or a set (using models) (M1.2.4)
identifying, describing with explanations, or illustrating equivalent fractions or mixed numbers (M1.2.4 & M3.2.5)

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of whole numbers to millions by
reading, writing, ordering, or [counting L] (M1.2.1)
identifying place value positions from tenths to millions (M1.2.2)
converting between whole numbers written in expanded notation and standard form (M1.2.4)

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of positive fractions with denominators 1 through 12 and 100 with proper and mixed numbers and benchmark percents (10%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 100%) by modeling, identifying, describing with explanations, or illustrating
equal parts of a whole, a region, or a set (M1.2.4)
equivalent fractions or mixed numbers (M1.2.4 & M3.2.5)

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of fractions (proper or mixed numbers), decimals, percents (whole number), or integers by
reading, writing, ordering, or [counting L] (M1.2.1)
[identifying place value positions from thousandths to millions L] (M1.2.2)
converting between whole numbers written in expanded notation and standard form (M1.2.4)

The student demonstrates conceptual understanding
  • of fractions, mixed numbers, or percents by [modeling L], identifying, describing, or illustrating
equal parts of a whole, a region, or a set (M1.2.4)
equivalent fractions or mixed numbers (M1.2.4 & M3.2.5)

The student demonstrates understanding
  • of rational numbers (fractions, decimals, percents, or integers) by
ordering rational numbers (M1.3.1)
[modeling (place value blocks) or identifying place value positions of whole numbers and decimals L] (M1.3.2)
converting between expanded notation (multiples of ten) and standard form for decimal numbers (M1.3.3)

The student demonstrates understanding
  • of positive fractions, decimals, or percents by
identifying or representing equivalents of numbers (M1.3.4 & M3.3.5)

The student demonstrates understanding
  • of real numbers by
ordering real numbers (M1.3.1)
distinguishing between a whole number in scientific notation and real numbers in standard form (M1.3.1)
converting between expanded notation (multiples of ten with exponents) and standard form (M1.3.3)
converting between a rational number in scientific notation and standard form (M1.4.4 & M 3.4.4)
equating different equivalent representations of the same exponential expression (e.g., 2³•2<sup>5</sup>=2<sup>8</sup>) (M1.4.4 & M3.4.4)
identifying their subsets (natural, whole, integers, rational, irrational) (M1.4.1)
simplifying expressions with positive and negative exponents (M1.4.4 & M3.4.4)
expressing square roots in simplest radical form (M1.4.4 & M3.4.4)

The student demonstrates understanding
  • of rational numbers (fractions, decimals, or percents including integers) by
identifying, describing, or illustrating equivalent representations (M1.3.4 & M3.3.5)
expressing products of numbers using exponents (M1.3.1 & M1.3.3)
Understanding Meaning of Operations
The student demonstrates conceptual understanding of mathematical operations by
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the processes of addition and subtraction of whole numbers and their relationships (M1.1.3)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the processes of multiplication (M1.2.3)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the relationship between multiplication and addition (M1.2.3)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the relationship between multiplication and division (M1.2.3)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the process of adding or subtracting fractions with like denominators (2 to 12) (M1.2.5)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the process of division and its relationship to subtraction or to multiplication (M1.2.3)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the process of adding and subtracting proper fractions or mixed numbers (like denominators) (M1.2.5)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the process of adding or subtracting decimals that represent money (M1.2.5)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the relationships among the four basic operations (M1.2.3)
[using models, explanations, number lines, or real-life situations L] describing or illustrating the process of adding and subtracting fractions with different denominators (M1.2.5)
using models, explanations, number lines, real-life situations, describing or illustrating the effects of arithmetic operations on rational numbers (fractions, decimals) (M1.2.3)
using models, explanations, number lines, real-life situations, describing or illustrating the effects of arithmetic operations on rational numbers (percents) (M1.2.3)
using models, explanations, number lines, real-life situations, describing or illustrating the use of inverse operations (addition/subtraction or multiplication/division) (M1.2.3)
using models, explanations, number lines, real-life situations, describing or illustrating the effects of arithmetic operations on real numbers (M1.4.3)
using models, explanations, number lines, real-life situations, describing or illustrating the use of inverse operations (squaring/square root) (M1.4.3 & 1.4.5)
describing or illustrating the effects of arithmetic operations on real numbers (M1.4.3)
describing or illustrating the use of inverse operations (cubing/cube root) (M1.4.3 & 1.4.5)
describing or illustrating [counting and adding in different bases L] (M1.4.2)
Number Theory
The student demonstrates conceptual understanding of number theory by
[describing or illustrating identity property of addition L] (M1.1.7)
[modeling (with manipulatives) and explaining commutative property of addition L] (M1.1.7)
identifying or using patterns in the number system (skip count by 2's, 5's, or 10's; add or subtract by 10; even or odd numbers) (M1.1.6)
[describing or illustrating identity property of multiplication L] (M1.2.7)
[modeling (with manipulatives) and explaining commutative property of multiplication L] (M1.2.7)
identifying or listing factors and multiples of a number (M1.2.6)
describing or illustrating commutative or identity properties of addition or multiplication using models or explanations (M1.2.7)
identifying or listing factors and multiples common to a pair or set of numbers (M1.2.6)
describing or illustrating commutative, [associative, inverse L] or identity properties of addition or multiplication using models or explanations (M1.2.7)
identifying or describing factors and multiples common to a pair or set of numbers (e.g., Least Common Multiple, L.C.M., or Greatest Common Factor, G.C.F.) (M1.2.6)
[modeling (base 10 blocks) distributive property L] (M1.3.6)
using commutative, [associative L], inverse, or identity properties with rational numbers (M1.3.6)
applying rules of divisibility to whole numbers (M1.3.5)
identifying prime and composite numbers (M1.3.5)
[using distributive property with rational numbers L] (M1.3.6)
applying the rules for order of operations to rational numbers (M1.3.5)
identifying or writing the prime factorization of a number using exponents (M1.3.5)
[using distributive property with real numbers L] (M1.3.6)
applying the rules for order of operations to real numbers and variables (M1.3.5)
[using distributive property with variables L] (M1.4.5)
identifying or applying commutative, identity, associative, inverse, or distributive properties to real numbers and variables (M1.4.5)
identifying or writing the prime factorization of a variable expression using exponents (M1.4.4)
Measurement: Select and use systems, units, and tools of measurement
Measurable Attributes
The student demonstrates understanding of measurable attributes by
[estimating length to the nearest inch or foot L] (M2.1.3)
comparing and ordering objects according to measurable attribute (calendar, length, [temperature, weight, area, or volume L]) (M2.1.1)
identifying or describing objects that are greater than, less than, or equal to a unit of measure (standard or non-standard) (M2.1.2)
selecting an appropriate unit of English, metric, or non-standard measurement to estimate the length, time, weight, or temperature (M2.1.3)
identifying coins, their value, or the value of a set of coins (M2.1.5)
[estimating length to the nearest half-inch or centimeter L] (M2.2.1)
[estimating temperature (degree Celsius or Fahrenheit) or weight (pounds or kilograms) to the nearest unit L] (M2.2.1)
identifying or using equivalent measures for length (inch, foot, yard: 12 inches = 1 foot, 3 feet = 1 yard, 36 inches = 1 yard; centimeter, meter: 100 centimeters = 1 meter) (M2.2.2)
selecting an appropriate unit of metric measurement to estimate length, weight or temperature (M2.2.1)
[estimating length to the nearest one-fourth inch or centimeter L] (M2.2.1)
[estimating temperature (degree Celsius or Fahrenheit, plus or minus 5 degrees) or weight (half-pounds or kilograms) to the nearest unit L] (M2.2.1)
identifying or using equivalent measures for weight/mass (16 oz. = 1 pound or 1000 grams = 1 kilogram) and length (1000 millimeters = 1 meter) or time (M2.2.2)
[estimating length to the nearest eighth-inch or millimeter L] (M2.2.1)

identifying equivalent measures within systems

English
  • length (inches, feet, yards, miles)
  • weight (ounces, pounds, [tons L])
  • volume (fluid ounces, cups, pints, quarts, gallons)
Metric
  • length (millimeters, centimeters, meters, kilometers)
  • volume (milliliters, liters) (M2.2.2)
[estimating length to the nearest sixteenth of an inch or millimeter, volume to the nearest cubic centimeter or milliliter or angle to the nearest 30 degrees L] (M2.3.1)
identifying or using equivalent English (square inches, square feet, square yards) or metric systems (square centimeters, square meters) (M2.3.2)
converting measurements within the same system (English or metric) (M2.3.2)
estimating or converting measurements between the English and metric systems in real-world applications, given a conversion factor (e.g., miles/kilometers) (M2.4.2)
converting square and cubic units within the same system, English or metric, in real-world applications (M2.4.2)
Measurement Techniques
The student demonstrates ability to use measurement techniques using pictorial representations [or manipulatives L] in real-world contexts by
[measuring length to the nearest half-inch (M2.1.3)
telling time to the nearest <font size="1"><sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub></font> hour using an analog clock or [distinguishing morning, afternoon, or evening L] (M2.1.4)
determining elapsed time using a calendar (M2.2.5)
[counting back change from $1.00 L] (M2.2.6)
measuring length to the nearest half-inch or [centimeter L] (M2.2.1, M2.2.3, & M2.2.4)
telling time in 5 minute increments using analog clocks (M2.2.5)
[counting back change from $5.00 L] (M2.2.6)
determining possible combinations of coins and bills to given amounts (M2.2.6)
[simulating multiple purchases and calculating the amount of change from a given bill(s) up to $50.00 L] (M2.2.6)
The student demonstrates ability to use measurement techniques by
[measuring temperature or weight using appropriate tools L] (M2.2.1 & M2.2.3)
telling time using analog clocks to the nearest minute and using A.M. or P.M. (M2.2.5)
determining possible combinations of coins and bills to given amounts (M2.2.6)
[simulating multiple purchases and calculating the amount of change from given bills up to $100.00 L] (M2.2.6)
measuring length to the nearest <font size="1"><sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub></font> inch or centimeter (M2.2.1)
The student uses measurement techniques by
using a scaled ruler to an eighth of an inch or millimeter on a map or drawing (M2.2.1 & M2.2.3)
calculating elapsed time (minutes, hours) (M2.2.5)
solving real-world problems involving elapsed time between U.S. time zones (including Alaska Standard time) (M2.2.5)
converting and using equivalent measurements within the same system (M2.2.2)
measuring length to the nearest 1/8 of an inch or nearest millimeter (M2.2.1)
applying a given scale factor to find missing dimensions of similar figures (M2.3.4)
measuring various dimensions to one-sixteenth of an inch or millimeter (M2.3.1)
accurately measuring a given angle using a protractor to the nearest plus or minus 2 degrees (M2.3.1)
solving real-world problems involving elapsed time between world time zones (M2.3.5)
using scale drawings involving indirect measurement (determining the scale factor and applying it to find missing dimension) (M2.3.4)
[modeling the conversion within the same system L] (M2.3.2)
applying indirect methods, such as the Pythagorean theorem to find missing dimensions, in real-world applications (M2.4.4)
[Applying right triangle trigonometry (sine, cosine, and tangent) to find missing dimensions in real-world applications L] (M2.4.4)
Estimation and Computation: Perform basic arithmetic functions, make reasoned estimates, and select and use appropriate methods or tools
Estimation
The student determines reasonable answers to real-life situations, paper/pencil computations, or calculator results by
finding "how many" or "how much" to 50 (M3.1.1)
estimating the results of simple addition and subtraction problems up to 1,000 (M3.1.1)

identifying or using [a variety of L] strategies (e.g., rounding to appropriate place value, multiplying by powers of ten, using front-end estimation) to estimate the results of whole number addition or subtraction computations to 10,000, or simple multiplication or division (M3.2.1)

identifying or using [a variety of L] strategies (e.g., rounding to appropriate place value, multiplying by powers of ten, using front-end estimation to estimate the results of addition or subtraction computations from tenths to 100,000, including money, or simple multiplication or division (M3.2.1)

identifying or using [a variety of L] strategies (e.g., truncating, rounding to compatible numbers) to estimate the results of addition, subtraction or multiplication from thousandths to millions or simple division (M3.2.1)
The student solves problems (including real-world situations) using estimation by
identifying or using [a variety of L] strategies, including truncating, rounding, front-end estimation, compatible numbers, to check for reasonableness of solutions (M3.3.1)
[comparing results of different strategies L] (M3.3.1)
[applying and assessing the appropriateness of a variety of estimation strategies L] (M3.3.1)
judging whether the strategy will result in an answer greater or less than the exact answer (M3.4.1)
[explaining why one strategy is more appropriate than another and determining why the estimation result is greater or less than the exact answer L] (M3.4.1)
Computation
The student accurately solves problems (including real-world situations) involving
[recalling basic addition and subtraction facts, sums to 20, and corresponding subtraction facts efficiently L] (M3.1.2)
adding or subtracting two-digit whole numbers (M3.1.3)
using repeated addition to model multiplication with whole numbers with products to 25 (M3.1.4)
using grouping or "sharing equally" to model division with whole numbers to 25 (M3.1.4)
[recalling basic multiplication facts, products to 100, and corresponding division facts efficiently L] (M3.2.2)
adding or subtracting three-digit whole numbers (M3.2.3)
multiplying two-digit numbers by single-digit numbers (M3.2.4)
adding fractions with like denominators to 12 (M3.2.3)
[recalling basic multiplication facts, products to 144, and corresponding division facts efficiently L] (M3.2.2)
adding or subtracting four-digit whole numbers, fractions with like denominators to 12, or decimals involving money (M3.2.3)
multiplying two-digit whole numbers by two-digit numbers or dividing three-digit whole numbers by single-digit numbers (M3.2.4)
[recalling basic addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division facts efficiently L] (M3.2.2)
adding or subtracting whole numbers, fractions with unlike denominators to 12, or decimals to the hundredths place (M3.2.3)

multiplying whole numbers by two- or three-digit numbers, dividing three-digit numbers by one or two-digit numbers, or multiplying or dividing decimals that represent money by whole numbers, or multiplying or dividing proper fractions (M3.2.4)
[developing or interpreting scale models (scale factors such as 1 in. = 1 ft.) L] (M3.2.6)
adding or subtracting fractions or mixed numbers with unlike denominators, or decimals to the thousandths place (M3.3.3)
multiplying or dividing decimals to hundredths, or multiplying or dividing by powers of ten, or multiplying or dividing fractions or mixed numbers (M3.3.4)
converting between equivalent fractions, terminating decimals, or percents (10% = 1/10 = 0.1) (M3.3.5)
solving proportions using a given scale (M3.3.6)
adding, subtracting, multiplying or dividing integers or positive rational numbers (M3.3.3 & M3.3.4)
percents and percentages (e.g., tax, discount) (M3.3.3 & M3.3.4)
converting between equivalent fractions, decimals, or percents (M3.3.5)
ratio and proportion (M3.3.6)
adding or subtracting rational numbers including integers with whole number exponents (M3.4.2)
multiplying or dividing rational numbers including integers with whole number exponents (M3.4.3)
determining rate by using ratio and proportion (M3.4.5)
[multiplying or dividing numbers in scientific notation L] (M3.4.3)
applying basic operations with real numbers using powers [and scientific notation L] (M3.4.2 & M3.4.3)
solving problems involving percent increase or decrease (M3.4.5)
Functions and Relationships: Represent, analyze, and use patterns, relations, and functions
Describing Patterns and Functions
The student demonstrates conceptual understanding of functions by
identifying a missing element in a pattern up to the next three terms (identifying a number using addition or subtraction or objects); or explaining how missing elements could be found (M4.1.1)
[expressing a generalization of a pattern using words L] (M4.1.1 & M4.1.2)
[using manipulatives, including a calculator, as tools when describing, extending, or representing patterns L] (M4.1.1 & M4.13)
The student demonstrates conceptual understanding of functions, patterns, or sequences by
extending patterns that use addition, subtraction, multiplication, or symbols, up to 10 terms, represented by models (function machine), tables, sequences, or in problem situations (M4.2.1)
[using rules to express the generalization of a pattern using words, lists, or tables L] (M4.2.4)
[using manipulatives, including a calculator, as tools when describing, extending, or representing a number sequence L] (M4.2.1 &M4.2.3)
extending patterns that use addition, subtraction, multiplication, division or symbols, up to 10 terms, represented by models (function machines), tables, sequences, or in problem situations (M4.2.1)
using rules to express the generalization of a pattern using words, lists, or tables (M4.2.4)
identifying or applying addition or subtraction patterns to find missing values in a function (M4.1.2)
[using manipulatives, including a calculator, as tools when describing, extending, or representing a number sequence L] (M4.2.1 & M4.2.3)

extending patterns (found in the number system, formed by multiples, factors, perfect squares up to 100, powers of ten), up to 10 terms, represented in tables, sequences, or in problem situations (M4.2.1)
using rules to express the generalization of a pattern using words, lists, or tables, with or without variables (M4.2.4)
identifying or applying multiplication or division patterns to find missing values in a function (M4.2.2)
[using manipulatives, including a calculator, as tools when describing, extending, or representing a number sequence L] (M4.2.1 & M 4.2.3)
The student demonstrates conceptual understanding of functions, patterns, or sequences including those represented in real-world situations by
describing or extending patterns (linear), up to ten terms, represented in tables, sequences, or in problem situations (M4.3.1)
generalizing relationships (linear) using a table of ordered pairs, a function, or an equation (M4.3.4)
describing in words how a change in one variable in a formula affects the remaining variables (how changing the length affects the area of a quadrilateral) (M4.3.2)
[using a calculator as a tool when describing, extending, or representing patterns L] (M4.3.3)
describing or extending patterns (linear), up to the nth term, represented in, tables, sequences, graphs, or in problem situations (M4.3.1)
generalizing relationships (linear) using a table of ordered pairs, a graph, or an equation (M4.3.4)
describing in words how a change in one variable in a formula affects the remaining variables (how changing the length affects the area of quadrilaterals or volume of a rectangular prism) (M4.3.2)
[using a calculator as a tool when describing, extending, or representing patterns L] (M4.3.3)
describing or extending patterns (families of functions: linear quadratic, absolute value,), up to the nth term, represented in tables, sequences, graphs, or in problem situations (M4.4.1)
generalizing relationships (linear, quadratic, absolute value,) using a table of ordered pairs, a graph, or an equation (M4.4.4)
describing in words how a change in one variable in a formula affects the remaining variables (e.g., how changing the radius affects the volume of a cylinder) (M4.3.2)
[using a calculator as a tool when describing, extending, representing, or graphing patterns or linear equations L] (M4.4.2)
describing or extending patterns (families of functions: linear, quadratic, absolute value), up to the nth term, represented in tables, sequences, graphs, or in problem situations (M4.4.1)
generalizing equations and inequalities (linear, quadratic, absolute value) using a table of ordered pairs or a graph (M4.4.4)
describing in words how a change in one variable or constant in an equation affects the outcome of the equation (M4.3.2)
[using a calculator as a tool when describing, extending, representing, or graphing patterns, linear or quadratic equations L] (M4.4.2)
Modeling and Solving Equations and Inequalities
The student demonstrates algebraic thinking by
using an open number sentence (addition or subtraction) to solve for an unknown represented by a box or circle (e.g., 5 + = 16, - 7 = 4, 5 + 2 = ) (M4.1.4)
using appropriate vocabulary or symbols for greater than, less than, or equal to (M4.1.4)
using an open number sentence (addition, subtraction or multiplication) to solve for an unknown represented by a box or circle (e.g., 9 • = 36, • 8 = 56, 3 • 6 = ) (M4.2.5)
using an open number sentence (addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division) to solve for an unknown represented by a box or circle (e.g., 256 ÷ = 8, ÷ 8 = 56, 36 ÷ 3 = ) (M4.2.5)
solving for an unknown represented by a letter, (addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division)  (e.g., 3 • n = 15, n – 5 = 12) (M4.2.5)
evaluating algebraic expressions (M4.3.5)

solving or identifying solutions to one-step linear equations of the form x±a=b or ax=b, where a and b are whole numbers, translating a story problem into an equation of similar form, or translating a story problem into an equation of similar form and solving it (M4.3.5)
translating a written phrase to an algebraic expression (M4.3.5)

solving or identifying solutions to two-step linear equations of the form ax±b =c, where a, b and c are rational numbers, and a≠0, translating a story problem into an equation of similar form, or translating a story problem into an equation of similar form and solving it (M4.3.5)
modeling (graphically or algebraically) or solving situations (including real-world applications) using systems of linear equations (M4.4.3)
solving or identifying solutions to multi-step linear equations of the form ax±b = cx±d, where a, b, c and d are rational numbers and a≠0, c≠0 (M4.4.2)
solving literal equations or formulas for a variable involving one step (e.g. solve for t when d=rt) (M4.4.2)
modeling (graphically or algebraically) or solving situations using systems of linear equations or inequalities (including real-world applications) (M4.4.3)
selecting and using the quadratic formula to solve problems (M4.4.2)

solving or identifying solutions to literal equations or formulas for a variable involving multi-steps (e.g., solve for h when A = <font size ="1"><sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub></font>h(b<sub>1</sub>+ b<sub>2</sub>) (M4.4.2)
Geometry: Construct, transform, and analyze geometric figures
Geometric Relationships
The student demonstrates an understanding of geometric relationships by
using the number or length of sides to identify, describe, [model L], or compare triangles or rectangles (including squares) (M5.1.1)

using the attributes and properties of plane figures to [model L], identify, compare, or describe plane figures (circles, rectangles, squares, and triangles)[and solid figures (cubes, cylinders, or spheres) L] (M5.1.1 & M5.1.2)
using the attributes and properties of angles to identify and compare triangles (acute, right, or obtuse) and regular polygons (M5.2.1)

using the attributes and properties of solid figures (edges, vertices, or the number or shape of faces) to [model L], identify, compare, or describe solid figures (cubes, cylinders, rectangular prisms, or spheres) (e.g., cans, dice, boxes, balls) (M5.2.2)

using the attributes and properties of angles and the number, length, and orientation of sides to identify or compare triangles (scalene, isosceles, or equilateral) or quadrilaterals (parallelograms, trapezoids, rhombi) (M5.2.1)

using the attributes and properties of solid figures (edges, vertices, number of faces) to [model L], identify, compare, or describe (cubes, cylinders, cones, spheres, pyramids, or rectangular prisms) (e.g., boxes, buildings, packages) (M5.2.2)
using the attributes and properties (sides and angles) of regular polygons to identify, classify, or compare regular or irregular polygons (M5.2.1)
identifying, comparing or describing attributes and properties of circles (radius, and diameter) (M5.2.2)

using the attributes and properties of prisms (vertices, length and alignment of edges, shape and number of bases, shape of faces) to [model L], identify, compare, or describe triangular or rectangular prisms (M5.2.2)
identifying a 3-dimensional shape from the 2-dimensional drawing of the shape (M5.2.2)
using the attributes and properties of polygons (diagonals, number of sides and angles) to identify and classify regular or irregular polygons (M5.3.1)
using the attributes and properties of prisms (vertices, length and alignment of edges, shape and number of bases, shape of faces) to identify and describe triangular or rectangular pyramids (M5.3.2)
[using the attributes and properties of regular polygons to sketch regular or irregular polygons L] (M5.3.1)
using the attributes and properties of solid figures (vertices, length and alignment of edges, shape and number of bases) to identify and describe cylinders and cones (M5.3.2)
using two-dimensional nets to create three-dimensional objects (prisms and cylinders) (M5.3.2)
identifying, analyzing, comparing, or using properties of angles (including supplementary or complementary) or circles (degrees in a circle) (M5.4.1)

identifying, analyzing, comparing, or using properties of plane figures:
  • supplementary, complementary or vertical angles
  • angles created by parallel lines with a transversal
  • sum of interior or exterior angles of a polygon
  • central angles, chords, inscribed angles or arcs of a circle (M5.4.1)
[using isometric drawings to create two-dimensional drawings of three-dimensional objects (shapes that are composites of rectangular right prisms) L] (M5.4.2)
Similarity, Congruence, Symmetry, and Transformation of Shapes
The student demonstrates conceptual understanding of similarity, congruence, symmetry, or transformations of shapes by
identifying, creating, or drawing lines of symmetry for real-world objects (e.g., block letters, flags, insects) (M5.1.3)
comparing or describing shapes (circles, triangles, or rectangles) as "larger than," "smaller than," or "congruent to," a given shape (M5.1.3)
illustrating or identifying the results of transformations (slides) of polygons (M5.1.5)
identifying or drawing all lines of symmetry to identify figures that are symmetrical (M5.2.3)
identifying shapes that are congruent (M5.2.3)
illustrating or identifying the results of transformations (turns) of polygons by continuing a given pattern (M5.2.5)
illustrating or identifying the results of transformation (slides, turns, or flips of polygons) (e.g., pictures of cultural art, fabric designs, architecture, logos) (M5.2.5)
identifying, creating, or drawing geometric figures that are congruent, similar, or symmetrical (M5.2.3)
[modeling designs (e.g., tessellations) that contain a series of slides, flips, and/or turns L] (M5.2.5)
identifying, creating, or drawing geometric figures that are congruent, similar, or symmetrical (M5.2.3)
[drawing or describing the results of transformations of polygons such as slides, turns, or flips L] (M5.2.5)
Transformation of Shapes
The student demonstrates conceptual understanding of similarity, congruence, symmetry, or transformations of shapes by
using a scale factor to solve problems involving similar shapes (e.g., scale drawings, maps) (M5.3.3)
[drawing or describing the results of applying transformations such as translations, rotations, reflections, or dilations to figures L] (M5.3.5)
using proportionality to solve real-world problems involving similar shapes (e.g., two real-world objects casting shadows) (M5.3.3)
identifying the results of applying transformations (translations, rotations, reflections, dilations) to figures on a coordinate plane (M5.3.5)
using a coordinate plane to solve problems involving congruent or similar shapes (M5.4.3)
[drawing or describing the results of applying transformations (translations, rotations, reflections, or dilations) to figures on a coordinate plane L] (M5.4.4)
identifying congruent and similar figures using Euclidean geometry (e.g., [constructions L], coordinate geometry) (M5.4.3)
using transformations to show congruence or similarity of figures on a coordinate plane (M5.4.4)
Perimeter, Area, Volume, and Surface Area
The student solves problems using perimeter or area by
estimating or determining area or perimeter of rectangular or square shapes on grids (M5.1.4)
estimating or determining area or perimeter of rectangles, squares and irregular shapes on grids with a key or ruler (M5.2.4)
The student solves problems (including real-world situations) using perimeter or area by
estimating or determining area or perimeter of rectangles using a key, ruler, or given measures (M5.2.4)
[estimating or determining the area and circumference of a circle using a grid or manipulatives L] (M5.2.4 & M5.3.4)
The student solves problems (including real-world situations) by using perimeter, area, or volume by
estimating or determining area or perimeter of polygons (parallelograms, trapezoids, triangles) using a key, ruler, or given measures (M5.2.4)
[estimating the area and circumference of a circle using a grid or manipulatives and comparing the relationship of the diameter to the circumference (p) L] (M5.2.4 & M5.3.4)
[estimating or determining the volume of a right rectangular prism using manipulatives and formulas (e.g., cereal box, sand box, planter) L] (M5.3.4)
The student solves problems (including real-world situations) by
determining the volume of cubes and rectangular prisms (M5.3.4)
determining the surface area of rectangular prisms (M5.3.4)
determining the circumference of a circle (M5.3.4)
determining the volume of right triangular prisms or cylinders (M5.3.4)
determining the surface area of cylinders or triangular prisms (M5.3.4)
determining the circumference and area of a circle (M5.3.4)
determining the volume or surface area of prisms, cylinders, cones or pyramids (M5.3.4)
determining the volume or surface area of spheres or compound solids (M5.3.4)
Position and Direction
The student demonstrates understanding of position and direction by
[using directional terms (inside, outside, right, left, horizontal, vertical) to describe relative location of objects in a picture L] (M5.1.6)
[describing the relative location of places or objects on a map using compass directions of north, south, east or west L] (M5.2.6)
[locating points of given coordinates on a grid or identifying coordinates for a given point (e.g., items on a treasure map) L] (M5.2.6)

graphing a vertical or horizontal line segment (given whole number coordinates for its end points) on a coordinate grid or identifying its length or midpoint (e.g., using a map to trace a route and calculate distance) (M5.2.6 & M5.2.7)
graphing or identifying values of variables on a coordinate grid (M5.3.6)
graphing or identifying relationships of variables on a coordinate plane (e.g., length/width, area/diameter, cost/pound) (M5.3.6)
The student demonstrates understanding of position and direction when solving problems (including real-world situations) by
graphing or identifying (using equations or formulas to determine the slope of line segments on a coordinate plane) (M5.4.5)
graphing a line segment on a coordinate grid and/or identifying its length or midpoint by using formulas (M5.4.5)
graphing a system of equations on a coordinate grid, identifying a solution, or determining their relationship (intersecting, parallel, perpendicular) (M5.4.5)
Construction
The student demonstrates a conceptual understanding of geometric drawings or constructions by
[drawing real-world objects that consist of geometric shapes (squares, rectangles, triangles, or circles) L] (M5.1.7)
[identifying or drawing parallel or intersecting line segments L] (M5.2.7)
[identifying or drawing perpendicular line segments or midpoints L] (M5.2.7)
[drawing or measuring quadrilaterals with given dimensions or angles L] (M5.3.7)
[drawing or measuring polygons with given dimensions and angles or circles with given dimensions L] (M5.3.7)
[drawing, measuring, or constructing geometric figures (polygons, perpendicular bisectors, or perpendicular or parallel lines) L] (M5.3.7)
[drawing, measuring, or constructing geometric models of plane figures (containing parallel and/or perpendicular lines) L] (M5.4.6)

[drawing, measuring, or constructing geometric models of plane figures (containing parallel and/or perpendicular lines, angles, perpendicular bisectors, congruent angles, regular polygons) L] (M5.4.6)
Statistics and Probability: Formulate questions, gather and interpret data, and make predictions
Data Display
The student demonstrates an ability to classify and organize data by

[designing an investigation and collecting, recording L], organizing, displaying, or explaining the classification of data in real-world problems (e.g., literature, self, or family), using bar graphs, and [Venn diagrams L] (M6.1.1, M6.1.2, & M6.1.5)

[designing an investigation and collecting L], organizing or displaying, using appropriate scale, data in real-world problems (e.g., social studies, friends, or school), using bar graphs, tables, charts, or diagrams with whole numbers up to 25 (M6.2.1 & M6.2.2)

[designing an investigation and collecting L], organizing, or displaying, using appropriate scale, data in real-world problems (e.g., social studies, friends, or school), using bar graphs, tables, charts, diagrams, or line graphs with whole numbers up to 50 (M6.2.1 & M6.2.2)

[designing an investigation and collecting L], organizing, or displaying, using appropriate scale for data displays (tables, bar graphs, line graphs, or circle graphs), data in real-world problems (e.g., social studies, friends, or school), with whole numbers up to 100 (M6.2.1 & M6.2.2)

[collecting, L] displaying, organizing, or explaining the classification of data in real-world problems (e.g., science or humanities, peers or community), using circle graphs, frequency distributions, stem and leaf, [or scatter plots L] with appropriate scale (M6.3.1)

[designing, collecting L], organizing, displaying, or explaining the classification of data in real-world problems (e.g., science or humanities, peers or community), using histograms, scatter plots, or box and whisker plots with appropriate scale [or with technology L] (M6.3.1)

[designing, collecting L], organizing, displaying, or explaining the classification of data in real-world problems (e.g., science or humanities, peers, community, or careers) using information from tables or graphs that display two sets of data [or with technology L] (M6.4.1)

[designing, collecting L], organizing, displaying, or explaining the classification of data in real-world problems (e.g., science or humanities, peers, community, or careers), using information from tables or graphs that display two or more sets of data [or with technology L] (M6.4.1)
Analysis and Central Tendency
The student demonstrates an ability to analyze data (comparing, explaining, interpreting, or justifying conclusions) by
using information from a variety of displays (tallies, tables, pictographs, bar graphs, or [Venn diagrams L] (M6.1.2)
using the terms "maximum" or "minimum" (M6.1.3)
The student demonstrates an ability to analyze data (comparing, explaining, interpreting, evaluating; or drawing or justifying conclusions) by
using information from a variety of displays (tables, bar graphs, or Venn diagrams) (M6.2.2)
using mode or range with up to 5 pieces of data with a value of 10 or less each (M6.2.3)
using information from a variety of displays (tables, bar graphs, line graphs, or Venn diagrams) (M6.2.2)
using mode, median, or range with up to 10 pieces of data with a value of 10 or less each (M6.2.3)
using information from a variety of displays (tables, bar graphs, line graphs, circle graphs, or Venn diagrams) (M6.2.2)
using mean, median, mode, or range (M6.2.3)
The student demonstrates an ability to analyze data (comparing, explaining, interpreting, evaluating or making predictions; or drawing or justifying conclusions) by
using information from a variety of displays (e.g., as found in graphical displays in newspapers and magazines) (M6.3.2)
determining range, mean, median, or mode (M6.3.3)
The student demonstrates an ability to analyze data (comparing, explaining, interpreting, evaluating, making predictions, or describing trends; or drawing, formulating, or justifying conclusions) by
using information from a variety of displays or analyzing the validity of statistical conclusions found in the media (M6.3.2)
determining or justifying a choice of range, mean, median, or mode as the best representation of data for a practical situation (M6.3.3)
using information from a variety of displays or analyzing the validity of statistical conclusions found in the media (M6.4.1)
using range and measures of central tendency to determine the best representation of the data for a practical situation (M6.4.3)
identifying and/or showing the meaning of a best fit line (M6.4.2)
using information from a display to solve a problem or analyzing the validity of statistical conclusions (M6.4.1 & M6.4.4)
using and justifying range and measures of central tendency to determine the best representation of the data for a practical situation (M6.4.3)
using a best fit line to describe trends and make predictions about data (M6.4.2)
Probability
The student demonstrates a conceptual understanding of probability by
[explaining the differences between chance and certainty or recognizing events that may be certain or chance events L] (M6.1.4)
[Finding and recording L] and making predictions about the likelihood of outcomes of a simple probability experiment (e.g., spinner, tossing a coin) (M6.1.4)
The student demonstrates a conceptual understanding of probability and counting techniques by
predicting or explaining the probability of all possible outcomes in a simple experiment (e.g., spinners, dice, coins) (M6.2.4)

determining possible combinations in a given situation involving up to 3 items (e.g., how many ways can you choose two fruits out of a basket containing oranges and bananas? –three ways: two bananas; one orange and one banana; and two oranges) (M6.2.5)
predicting or explaining the probability of all possible outcomes in an experiment using ratios or fractions to describe the probability (M6.2.4)
solving or identifying solutions to problems involving money combinations (e.g., how many ways can you make 25 cents using nickels, dimes, or quarters?) (M6.2.5)
[analyzing whether a game is mathematically fair or unfair by explaining the probability of all possible outcomes L] (M6.2.4)

solving or identifying solutions to problems involving possible combinations (e.g., if ice cream sundaes come in 3 flavors with 2 possible toppings, how many different sundaes can be made using only one flavor of ice cream with one topping?) (M6.2.5)
determining the [experimental L] and theoretical probability of a simple event (M6.3.5)
using a systematic approach to finding sample spaces or to making predictions about the probability of independent events (M6.3.5)
[designing and conducting a simulation to study a problem and communicate the results L] (M6.3.6)
determining or comparing the experimental and/or theoretical probability of simple events (M6.3.5)
using a systematic approach to finding sample spaces or to making predictions about the probability of independent events and using the information to solve real-world problems (M6.3.5)
[designing and conducting a simulation to study a problem and communicate the results L] (M6.3.6)
determining or comparing the experimental and/or theoretical probability of independent or dependent events (M6.4.5)
making predictions about the probability of independent or dependent events and using the information to solve problems (M6.4.5)
[designing, conducting, analyzing, and communicating the results of a probability experiment L] (M6.4.6)
explaining in words or identifying the difference between experimental and theoretical probability of independent or dependent events (M6.4.5)
analyzing data to make predictions about the probability of independent or dependent events as a basis for solving real-world problems (M6.4.5)
[designing, conducting, analyzing, and communicating the results of a multi-stage probability experiment L] (M6.4.6)

text: Content Standards B, C, D, and E: Process skills and abilities

children.text: Applying conceptual knowledge and skills as designated in all strands of Content Standard A by problem solving, communicating, reasoning, and making connections
Problem solving: Understand and be able to select and use a variety of problem-solving strategies
The student demonstrates an ability to problem solve by
selecting and applying an appropriate strategy (e.g., guess and check; draw a picture; make a model, extend a pattern) to solve a variety of problems (M7.1.2)
selecting and applying appropriate strategy (e.g., lists, guess and check; extended patterns) to solve a variety of problems (M7.2.2)
explaining and verifying results of an original problem and applying what was learned to new situations (M7.2.3)

selecting and applying an appropriate strategy (e.g., tables, charts, lists, or graphs; guess and check; extended patterns; make a model) to solve a variety of problems and verify the results (M7.2.2)
explaining and verifying results of an original problem and applying what was learned to new situations (M7.2.3)

selecting, modifying, and applying appropriate problem solving strategies (e.g., graphing, Venn diagrams, tables, lists, working backwards, guess and check, or extend a pattern) and verifying results (M7.3.2)
evaluating and interpreting solutions to problems (M7.3.3)
selecting, modifying, and applying a variety of problem-solving strategies (e.g., working backwards, drawing a picture, Venn diagrams and verifying the results) (M7.3.2)
evaluating, interpreting, and justifying solutions to problems (M7.3.3)
selecting, modifying, and applying a variety of problem-solving strategies (e.g., inductive and deductive reasoning, Venn diagrams, making a simpler problem) and verifying the results (M7.3.2)
evaluating, interpreting, and justifying solutions to problems (M7.3.3)
selecting, modifying, and applying a variety of problem-solving strategies (e.g., charts, graphing, inductive and deductive reasoning, Venn diagrams) and verifying the results (M7.4.2)
evaluating, interpreting, and justifying solutions to problems by using an alternative strategy (M7.4.3)
applying multi-step, integrated, mathematical problem-solving strategies (M7.4.2)
verifying the answer by using an alternative strategy (M7.4.3)
Communication: Form and use appropriate methods to define and explain mathematical relationships
The student communicates his or her mathematical thinking by

representing mathematical problems using manipulatives, models, pictures, and/or everyday language; or using everyday language to explain thinking about the problem-solving strategies and solutions to problems (M8.1.1, M8.1.2, & M8.1.3)

representing problems using mathematical language including concrete, pictorial, and/or symbolic representation; or by organizing and communicating mathematical problem-solving strategies and solutions to problems (M8.2.1, M8.2.2, & M8.2.3)

representing problems using mathematical language including concrete, pictorial, and/or symbolic representation; or organizing and communicating mathematical problem-solving strategies and solutions using mathematical language (M8.2.1, M8.2.2, & M8.2.3)

representing problems using mathematical language including concrete, pictorial, and/or symbolic representation; or using appropriate vocabulary, symbols, and technology to explain mathematical solutions (M8.2.1, M8.2.2, & M8.2.3)

representing mathematical problems numerically, graphically, and/or symbolically; or using appropriate vocabulary, symbols, or technology to explain, justify, and defend strategies and solutions (M8.3.1, M8.3.2, & M8.3.3)

representing mathematical problems numerically, graphically, and/or symbolically, translating among these alternative representations; or using appropriate vocabulary, symbols, or technology to explain, justify, and defend strategies and solutions (M8.3.1, M8.3.2, & M8.3.3)

representing mathematical problems numerically, graphically, and/or symbolically, translating among these alternative representations; or using appropriate vocabulary, symbols, or technology to explain, justify, and defend strategies and solutions (M8.4.1, M8.4.2, & M8.4.3)

representing mathematical problems numerically, graphically, and/or symbolically communicating math ideas in writing; or using appropriate vocabulary, symbols, or technology to explain, justify, and defend strategies and solutions (M8.4.1, M8.4.2, & M8.4.3)
Reasoning: Use logic and reason to solve mathematical problems
The student demonstrates an ability to use logic and reason by
drawing conclusions about mathematical problems; or finding examples that support or refute mathematical statements (M9.1.1 & M9.1.2)
explaining whether or not a prediction, estimation, or solution is reasonable (M9.1.3)
drawing conclusions about mathematical problems (given a rule or generalization, determine whether the example fits) or justifying answers and mathematical strategies (M9.2.1, M9.2.2, & M9.2.3)

drawing logical conclusions about mathematical situations (given a rule or generalization, determine whether the example fits); or justifying answers and mathematical strategies as reasonable (M9.2.1, M9.2.2, & M9.2.3)
using informal deductive reasoning in concrete contexts; or justifying answers and mathematical strategies using examples (M9.3.1 & M9.3.3)

using informal deductive and inductive reasoning in concrete contexts or stating counterexamples to disprove statements; or justifying and defending the validity of mathematical strategies and solutions using examples (M9.3.1, M9.3.2, & M9.3.3)

generalizing from patterns of observations (inductive reasoning) about mathematical problems and testing using a logical verification (deductive reasoning); or justifying and defending the validity of mathematical strategies and solutions using examples and counterexamples (M9.3.1, M9.3.2, & M9.3.3)
following and evaluating an argument, judging its validity using inductive, or deductive reasoning and logic; or making and testing conjectures (M9.4.1 & M9.4.2)
using methods of proof including direct, indirect, and counter examples to validate conjectures (M9.4.3)
Connections: Apply mathematical concepts and processes to situations within and outside of school
The student understands and applies mathematical skills and processes across the content strands by
using real-world contexts such as literature, self, and family (M10.1.1. & M10.1.2)
using real-world contexts such as social studies, friends, and school (M10.2.1 & M10.2.2)
using real-world contexts such as social studies, friends, and school (M10.2.1 & M10.2.2)
using real-world contexts such as social studies, friends, school and community (M10.2.1, M10.2.2, &M10.3.2)
using real-world contexts such as science, humanities, peers, and community (M10.3.1 & M10.3.2)
using real-world contexts such as science, humanities, peers, community, and careers (M10.3.1 & M10.4.2)
using real-world contexts such as science, humanities, peers, community, careers, and national issues (M10.4.1 & M10.4.2)
using real-world contexts such as global issues and careers (M10.4.1 & M10.4.2)
